aboutMeDesc: a chemical engineer turned full-stack and software developer with a passion for solving complex problems through innovative coding solutions.
hireMeMain: I Am Available For Freelancer Projects.
hireMeText: With a robust engineering background, I bring a unique perspective to solving problems. Let's work together to bring your projects to life with precision and creativity.

contactMeSent: Thank you for your email! I have received your message and will be in touch soon.

portfolio1Intro: Streamline your visibility online with my customizable devPortfolio template.
portfolio2Intro: Interactive visualization of BFS, DFS, and Dijkstra's algorithms on a customizable grid. Draw walls, set start and end points, and watch the algorithm find the shortest path in real-time.
portfolio3Intro: Real-time weather data with city search, current conditions, and 5-day forecast.
portfolio4Intro: Live markdown editor with real-time preview and HTML export functionality.

portfolio7Intro: Focus timer using the Pomodoro technique with customizable intervals and session tracking.
portfolio8Intro: Parse chemical formulas and calculate molecular weights with element breakdown and composition pie chart.

mdSubtitle: Write markdown on the left, see the preview on the right
mazeQueuesStacksDesc: Many algorithms utilize data structures that allow them to run more efficiently. DFS and BFS use two of the most commonly used data structures – queues and stacks.
mazeQueueDesc: Queues follow the first-in-first-out principle – like a line at a store where whoever arrives first gets served first. Two operations: enqueue (insert at back) and dequeue (remove from front).
mazeStackDesc: Stacks follow the last-in-first-out principle – like a stack of books where you can only add or remove from the top. Two operations: push (insert at top) and pop (remove from top).
mazeBfsDesc: BFS explores all neighbors at the current depth before moving deeper. It uses a queue and a parent dictionary to track relationships. BFS guarantees finding the shortest path in an unweighted graph.
mazeDfsDesc: DFS explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking. It uses a stack to push and pop nodes at each iteration. DFS is simpler but does not guarantee finding the shortest path.
